results.title: Robocop 2 (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Orion Pictures Corporation, Jon Davison and Irvin Kershner
results.brief_description: In the pollution-ridden future, the city of Detroit is crumbling into decay and poverty. The drug-lords have introduced a new drug, Nuke, which is so seductive a majority of the population have become addicted to it. The only solution to the spiralling catastrophe of crime is the superhuman strength of Robocop, the world’s most efficient crime-fighting machine. This fast- paced, action-crammed sequel features superb special effects. Stars Peter Weller and Nancy Allen.

results.title: Robinson Crusoe (Gibba)
results.creator_credit: Corona Cinematografica, IFE International and Gibba
results.brief_description: Daniel Defoe’s famous adventure story is brought to life by the distinct style of the Italian animator, Gibba. Screen adaptation and script by Alan Thornton, Albert Chimenz, Frank Driver and Antony Victor. Dialogue by Alan Thornton.

results.title: Robinson Crusoe
results.creator_credit: Avant Films, Mario Marzac and Rene Cardona Jnr
results.brief_description: This is the classic tale of the castaway Crusoe, as told by a narrating tiger that witnesses his struggles to survive the man-eating cannibals that have landed on the tropical island where he washed up. Hugo Stiglitz plays Daniel Defoe’s famous hero.

results.title: Robinson Crusoe
results.creator_credit: Air Programs International, Walter J Hucker and Leif Gram
results.brief_description: Scottish sailor, Alexander Selkirk is believed to be the inspiration behind Daniel Defoe’s famous novel. Intrigued by Selkirk’s tale of being marooned in 1704 on a Pacific island for four and a half years, Defoe called his imaginative account, ‘The Life and strange surprising adventures of Robinson Crusoe’. This adventure story is brought to life through animation that will appeal to children and adults alike.

results.title: Robinson Charley: the story of our island from 1690-1960
results.creator_credit: Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films, John Halas and Joy Batchelor
results.brief_description: One of a series of animated cartoons about the man-in-the-street character “Charley” created to present information about Government legislation on various subjects to the publc. “Robinson Charley” sketches the economic history of Britain from 1690-1960. “Charley” builds up wealth through trade with other lands until he is hard hit by two wars and has to roll up his sleeves to restore his position.

results.title: Robin Hood Junior (Captioned)
results.brief_description: Lord Gilbert is away at the Crusades and the evil Baron has taken over Locksay Castle. Lord Gilbert’s daughter, Marion, flees the castle with the Great Seal of Locksay. The Baron wants it back but he hasn’t counted on the youthful cunning of Robin and the village children. Rated: G

results.title: Robin Campbell: old feller now: memories of a Muruawarri (A)
results.creator_credit: Goodgabah Productions, Alec Morgan and Martha Ansara
results.brief_description: Robin Campbell, an old man of the Murrawarri tribe of the far north west of New South Wales recalls, through dramatic re-enactments by his young relations, how he was taught, as a child, to hunt the emu and make animal tracks, and how he worked as a drover in the 1930’s and 40’s. Narrated by Bill Reid.

results.title: Robert Richard Torrens
results.creator_credit: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, Frank Bagnall and Lilias Fraser
results.brief_description: An account of the origin and history of the Torrens Title System. Shows Torrens’ work as Registrar-General and Member of Parliament, in the securing of land tenure in South Australia. Insecurity had plagued early settlers in South Australia, until Torrens’ land title reform bill was passed in 1857. Unsatisfactory registered transactions were replaced by a single certificate, one copy being held by the Registrar-General and the other by the owner.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, Frank Bagnall and Lilias Fraser

results.title: Robert Mapplethorpe
results.brief_description: Mapplethorpe’s studies of nude black men were a shameless affirmation of gay sexuality. He has been credited with helping to formulate a sense of gay identity in New York, but as one of the most successful photographers of modern time, his work has also been instrumental in restoring the male nude to mainstream art. This program charts Mapplethorpe’s career from student to leading figure in the art world.
